root.para: The value of an option during its life has two components: the intrinsic value and time value. The term is defined in the FASB ASC glossary as the amount by which fair value of the underlying stock exceeds the exercise price of an option (or the difference between the underlying spot price and option exercise price, which would be the strike rate, in this case study) if that difference is positive for the option holder. Intrinsic value is the net amount that would be realized upon immediate exercise of the option and sale of the underlying instrument (foreign currency, in this case study), and it can never be negative for the option holder. intrinsic value
